description:
Coccidioides immitis is a dimorphic fungus that is the causative agent of coccidioidomycosis, also known as Valley Fever. It is a soil-dwelling organism found primarily in the Southwestern United States, Mexico, and parts of Central and South America.

The fungus exists in two distinct forms:

1. Mycelial form: In the environment, C. immitis grows as a mycelium, which can produce infectious spores called arthroconidia. These spores can become airborne and be inhaled by humans, leading to the development of the disease.

2. Spherule form: Once the arthroconidia are inhaled, they transform into larger, spherical structures called spherules within the human host. These spherules mature and rupture, releasing endospores that can then infect nearby cells, leading to the progression of the disease.

C. immitis is a significant public health concern in regions where it is endemic, as it can cause a range of clinical manifestations, from mild, self-limiting respiratory illness to severe, disseminated disease, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. Understanding the biology and ecology of this fungus is crucial for developing effective prevention and treatment strategies for coccidioidomycosis.
